As a social action strategy, every Times story--and readers comment--has buttons for social media networks! Use them. Let the people's voices be heard!

Please, post readers comments to social media, along with the story or column (or without it!). This shares our views, explains our positions, and tells how and why we have made our decisions. Without amplifying our voice, we are wasting our voice. The Times is one of the very few news sites to give each reader's comment its own social media buttons. Let's use them! Forward to November!

I have often wondered whether the United States isn't at the stage the Roman Republic was in the first century BC, when money and military power corrupted politics so completely that the only way the state and society could survive was under an enlightened dictatorship. We might be lucky to get a leader as moderate and sensible as the Emperor Augustus (and many if not most of his successors), rather than a replay of the Inquisition under an evangelical Christian strongman (or strong-woman, like Michele Bachman, only smarter?). A revitalized USA under Augustus-like leaders might enjoy several more centuries of strength and vitality, before passing away - as all states and societies do in the end.

Living in New York when the financial crisis started in 2008, it almost seems like the world was coming to an end.  First few months of 2009 when the effects of this collapse started melting the rest of the economy in earnest I though it would take at least a decade or more to restore the losses from this recession.  I find it entirely laughable, (if it weren't so tragic), all these people who think that somehow the economy should be magically not just better, but improved upon in a few short years. They measure from the day Obama took office as if he had any ability to impact the economy on day one.  Well folks, the economy has improved.  I count the improvement starting from in mid 2009, the earliest that any Obama policies actually were in position to make any impact and when the Bush policies that caused the meltdown were finally in check.  Looking from there, the economy and employment picture has improved quite a lot, and obviously the financial sector is back to business as usual, and repaying their bailouts.   I've come to the conclusion that the American people don't want a president, they want a Messiah, someone who can walk on water and wave a magic wand and happy days will be here again.  There is no magic wand, the restoration of the American middle class will take years, a lot of hard work, some sacrifice in restoration of the Clinton years tax rates as the economy improves so the debt can be handled.    Romney will bring the Bush Years redux-bad move.

GMO crops do reproduce.. However, most buy new seed as it has better plant and yield genetics. Additionally, the seed producer has intellectual property rights, just like drug manufacturers- so you must pay them, normally by purchasing seed.

This is why you hear that Monsanto or some other company is suing farmers, because they will inspect fields of farms for its seed DNA. If you have it in a significant number (normally over 5% of total population) you must pay the "technology fee"

The problem with resistance is the "set aside or refuge acres" Monsanto and USDA have specific amounts of acreage you must plant to non-GMO crops(normally 5-20%). This allows the insects to interbreed with non tolerant insects.... leaving all off spring to be susceptible to the plants defenses.

...I will also add that they should be rotating crops... Look to our southern cotton belt. They rotate with soybeans and maybe a 3rd cover crop that holds soil moisture and adds organic matter while preventing erosion.  this is why the 3rd world can not compete with the US... Education. The typically lack the knowledge to farm with the environment.

I've worked in the tech sector for over 25 years. Some of my co-workers identify as "Conservatives" and strongly endorse the Republican platform. In speaking with them, people I work with every day, I find that they place much faith in the morals espoused by the Right, which leads them to defend the platform Mitt is running on based on ideals such as "faith", "Right to Life", opposition to LGBT lifestyles, and other such moral concepts rather than on popularly viewed "Liberal" ideals such as "equality for all", individual rights superseding corporate rights, and the role of government as protector of those with lesser (or nonexistent) voices.

What does this mean? I see at is a fundamental attack on the role of government in citizen's lives.

I feel that individuals have the right AND the responsibility to make their own choices and live with the consequences of their actions. I feel the role of government is to function as a facilitator, allowing the most people the most freedom to make those choices, stepping in only when such choices interfere with the well being of the whole. Government is NOT the arbiter of morality, "We, The People" are.

Robert Heinlein noted that people will vote for perceived "bread and circuses", right up until the bread is moldy & the circuses fail. That's when they decide to throw the rascals (they voted for) out and elect a new set of rascals.

We as a nation need to stop voting with our hearts and try voting with our brains.

If Romney wins, repeals or guts Dodd-Frank, the odds are that Financial Crisis II will quickly leas us into The economic abyss. The most amazing thing about Romney's policies is that they will cause Wall Street Bankes to jump out their windows and turn the big money men like Adelson into paupers.

Romney is a lot of things but he is not stupid. He knows that the odds are in favor of a major economic upturn in the next year or two and he plans on taking responsibility for it if he is elected. The sad part is that 95% of the public will believe that he is responsible.

The truth is, Presidents just like most of us, are to a large degree victims of the economic times and the corporate powers that really run this Country.

As my old teacher Paul Samuelson used to say, back in the early 1970's, most recessions were made in Washington by the Federal Reserve. Tight monetary policy was always reliable at creating recessions. Eisenhower had three recessions in eight years. Undoing a recession caused by tight money is pretty easy. Ease money. The sectors like housing and autos that are sensitive to low interest rates come bouncing back. The stock market likes low interest rates and also goes up. People feel wealthier and spend more.

The financial crises do not respond to monetary policy. People have too much debt. They are cutting their spending to pay down debt. Pushing interest rates down to zero does not stimulate demand very quickly. In the aftermath of a housing bubble the most powerful counter cyclical industry (housing) is not going to contribute to the recovery.

I just want to scream when Romney says that we have come out of other recessions much quicker than this one, and no one corrects him, not even the Obama campaign.  As only Dr. Krugman seems to know, all recessions are not the same.  Most recessions are short and can be righted with a little Keynesian economics, which both Republican and Democratic presidents have used.  The ones resulting from financial meltdowns like the one in 2008-2009 take years to recover from.  Since Herbert Hoover did too little too late to address the recession of 1930-1932, it became a full-blown depression, the Great Depression, a worldwide event that lasted a decade.  Only the stimulus of World War II spending ended the calamity.  Thankfully, Obama acted as forcefully as he could, given Republican obstructionism, to right the economic ship and keep us from experiencing another depression and the last three years have seen constant, if slow, growth.  Romney's policies, as far as they can be discerned, are closer to the austerity programs of Europe, which is experiencing a double-dip recession.

Romney's debt reduction policies will gut medicare and medicaid and his rejection of
the Affordable Care Act will only drain the economy further as the cost of the uninsured will rise and the productivity of a work force will be depressed with out realistic movement toward an economic and effective health care system.

However, Romney's has also proposed to cut taxes and keep up our high defense spending. Aside from the practicality of the former and the morality of the latter, could not both of these projects be considered a stimulus to the economy? Of course (even though he denies the facts) he will be getting us into greater debt for the short term in order to pay for all this but isn't that pretty similiar to the debt a Kensyian is willing to risk in order to make government grants that get the economy rolling?

"I know how to use dozens of software sets, several different OSs and I can learn whatever new mess you throw at me. The only question is whether I want to and whether it is worth the bother."

...and whether one has the time/money/energy. I like using different OSs and I like trying new things. My dad was a gadget nut, and I've inherited that in spades. :) And if I won the lottery tomorrow, messing around with tech would be one of the ways I would spend my time. But I've got two livings to earn, a parent to look after, and practical life errands to attend to. All of those are detailed, in-flux situations even before you factor in keeping up with the OSs and apps I already have. Result--I only upgrade Windows and Apple when absolutely forced to. And since that taps out to every other upgrade or so, well...

I would make a firm prediction here: Microsoft, much to its chagrin, will likely be forced to continue making the old Windows system available for years to come. I have not tried the new version, but this whole deal of changing everything out every four or five years is getting beyond ridiculous. I recall that one or two changes ago, some funny emails surfaced of high level employees at Microsoft who couldn't figure out how to use it.

There's nothing wrong with the idea of a new, better product and, sometimes, those products have to represent a sharp departure from the past. Trying to reverse obsolete desktops and laptops by showing how cool and forward thinking you are with tablets and smart phones is really dumb.

The new era, or the future, is not one in which people stop using laptops. Sorry, kids. I have a car, I use a van for certain public service duties and I ride a bike. I don't expect them all to become one thing just because someone invents a really cool bike that half the world goes nuts for. I still need the car. (I would like an airplane, too, please.)

What we are seeing is fadism, driven by the idea that the latest, newest thing is the only one that matters. I know how to use dozens of software sets, several different OSs and I can learn whatever new mess you throw at me. The only question is whether I want to and whether it is worth the bother. I will not be your slave to prove I can keep up with things.

We should look at history to see whether high or low taxes on the Rich are good for the economy.

In 1946 the public debt was 109% of the GDP (it is about 65% today), It went straight down to about 24% in 1973. During this period 1946 - 1973 taxes on the Rich were much higher. Marginal rates were at least 70%; they were 93% under Eisenhower. The economy was better than what we now have. For example, median wages went up rapidly;since 1973, they have stagnated. CEO's earned 50 times what their workers earned; it is 500 times today. (And please don't tell me these CEO's were more enlightened because Europe was devastated. They took less because of a very high marginal rate.) Starting in 1973, the percent of wealth and income taken by the richest 10%, 1%, and 0.1% has gone up at an ever increasing rate.

On the flip side, since 1900 the periods with the lowest marginal rates were the years leading up to 1929 and 2008. These were also the periods when economic inequality and speculation were the greatest and they led to disaster. When tax rates are high, since rich people hate to pay taxes, they leave their profits in their companies, pay their workers more, improve their means of production, and perhaps even hire more, but when rates are low, they take them out and ... speculate!

We should raise taxes on the Rich, not because it is fairer, not because of the increased revenue, but because it is better for the economy.

Paul Krugman is right that the financial crisis of 2008 forced most households to deleverage, depressing aggregate demand, and increasing unemployment.

He is also right that Obama had the right rhetoric but introduced a $787 billion financial stimulus that was way to small for the unemployment problem he faced. Yes, he faced opposition from Congress, but the the President is supposed to be a leader. Unlike FDR, Obama was mostly missing in action during his first (and perhaps only) term.

Of the $787 billion, only about $100 billion went to the much touted infrastructure spending that standard Keynesian theory teaches will create jobs. Much of the rest were transfer payments (which were important) and lower taxes, which come right out of the Republican playbook. Most likely McCain would have presented a similar stimulus program.

But America's financial crisis is not entirely cyclical in nature. And American incomes were dropping during the period 2000-07, when the US was stimulating aggregate demand through unsustainable borrowing. We cannot go completely back to those days.

There are underlying problems in the economy that are not addressed by Keynesian theory. One of those is the deficit, which has made it more difficult for the US to adopt the Keynesian policies it needed right after the crisis.

Krugman admits that economics is not as much of a science as we would like. In the long term the standard models omit one of the crucial variables: population growth.
